study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of priming and cross-priming in mitigating stress caused by waterlogging and dehydration in soybean plants (Glycine max).
results_summary: Priming and cross-priming significantly increased antioxidant enzyme activity, total soluble sugars, amino acids, and proline while reducing hydrogen peroxide and lipid peroxidation under waterlogging and dehydration stress. Under waterlogging, priming also suppressed fermentative activity and increased carbohydrate content.
population_specificity: Soybean plants (Glycine max) at vegetative and reproductive stages.
study_duration: Two stress periods of 5 days each, with recovery in between.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of melatonin and Bacillus thuringiensis on soybean plants under drought stress, focusing on growth, biochemical responses, and anatomical features.
results_summary: Melatonin and Bacillus treatments improved growth, chlorophyll content, and anatomical structures while reducing oxidative stress markers and enhancing antioxidant enzyme activity in drought-stressed soybean plants.
population_specificity: Soybean plants (cv. Giza 111) under drought conditions.
effective_dosage: Melatonin at 100 μM (foliar spray), Bacillus thuringiensis at 10^6-8 CFU/cm³ (seed treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether graphitic carbon nitride nanosheets (g-C3N4 NSs) could mitigate cadmium (Cd) toxicity in soybean (Glycine max L.) and enhance nitrogen fixation under Cd-contaminated soil conditions.
results_summary: g-C3N4 NSs reduced Cd toxicity, improved soybean growth, redistributed Cd to less harmful forms, and enhanced nitrogen fixation by stimulating nodulation and restoring nodule development. The treatment increased shoot and root dry weights and nitrogen content significantly under Cd stress.
population_specificity: Soybean plants (Glycine max L.) grown in Cd-contaminated soil.
effective_dosage: 100 mg kg-1 g-C3N4 NSs applied to soil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether glycine (Gly) alone or combined with Pediococcus pentosaceus R1 (Pp) improves the physicochemical properties, oxidative stability, and taste quality of Harbin dry sausages.
results_summary: The Gly + Pp combination significantly improved moisture content, water activity, pH, lactic acid bacteria count, redness, oxidative stability, and taste quality compared to other groups. The combined treatment also resulted in superior taste characteristics, as confirmed by electronic tongue and sensory evaluations.
population_specificity: Harbin dry sausages (food product study, not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on application in sausages, not human dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether DMOG-pretreated human umbilical cord MSCs (hUC-MSCs) could enhance therapeutic efficacy in lupus nephritis by improving anti-inflammatory and antifibrotic effects.
results_summary: DMOG-pretreated hUC-MSCs reduced inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IFN-γ, IL-6) and fibrosis markers (Fn, Colα1, Colα3), improved renal structure, and downregulated TGF-β/Smad signaling in a mouse lupus nephritis model.
population_specificity: Mouse model of lupus nephritis (systemic lupus erythematosus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of chemical mutagens (SA, EMS, MMS) on soybean varieties (SL958 and SL744) to identify mutants with the highest yield and improved traits.
results_summary: The study found that 0.4% sodium azide (SA) treatment in SL958 soybeans resulted in the highest germination, plant height, leaf count, leaf area, yield, and protein content compared to other treatments and controls. The SL744 variety showed comparatively lower improvements with the same treatment.
population_specificity: Soybean varieties (SL958 and SL744) grown in an agricultural research farm in Punjab, India.
effective_dosage: 0.2%, 0.4%, and 0.6% concentrations of SA, EMS, and MMS.
study_duration: Several weeks after sowing (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of post-translational modifications (specifically S-acylation) in GlyT2 and its impact on lipid raft inclusion and function.
results_summary: The study found that GlyT2 undergoes reversible S-acylation in spinal cord membranes, and mutations in cysteine residues predicted to be palmitoylated reduce its inclusion in lipid rafts. This effect was also observed with the palmitoylation inhibitor 2-bromopalmitate.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal or in vitro models, given the biochemical focus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of glycine and glutamate as glutathione (GSH) precursors on the growth rate, nutrient digestion, and blood concentration levels in weaning pigs.
results_summary: Supplementation with GSH precursors led to a linear increase in body weight, average daily gain, and feed efficiency (G:F ratio) in weaning pigs, but had no effect on nutrient digestibility or blood profile.
population_specificity: 180 crossbred weaning pigs with an average body weight of 7.94 ± 1.53 kg.
effective_dosage: 0.10%, 0.20%, and 0.30% GSH precursor supplementation in diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify metabolic vulnerabilities, particularly in serine-glycine-one-carbon (SGOC) metabolism, in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) patients to improve prognosis and therapeutic responses.
results_summary: The study found that SGOC metabolism is linked to aggressive tumor properties and poor prognosis in HNSCC. Targeting IMPDH1, a key enzyme in purine biosynthesis, suppressed cancer cell proliferation and metastasis, suggesting Glycine-related metabolic pathways as potential therapeutic targets.
population_specificity: Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antitumor effects of brucine, a glycine antagonist, on prostate cancer and its mechanisms in regulating amino acid metabolic pathways.
results_summary: Brucine treatment significantly reduced cell viability, proliferation, invasion, and migration while promoting apoptosis in DU-145 prostate cancer cells. It also downregulated GNMT expression, reducing sarcosine accumulation and inhibiting tumor progression.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer cell line DU-145 and normal prostatic epithelial cells RWPE-1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role and mechanism of cysteine and glycine-rich protein 2 (CSRP2) in neuroblastoma progression and its correlation with patient prognosis.
results_summary: High CSRP2 expression was linked to worse prognosis in neuroblastoma patients. CSRP2 knockdown reduced cell proliferation, migration, and increased apoptosis, while overexpression had the opposite effects, mediated through ERK1/2 activation.
population_specificity: Children with neuroblastoma (NB), specifically high-risk (INSS stages 3/4) and low-risk (INSS stages 1/2) cases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether glycine-proline-glutamate (GPE) could protect against amyloid-β-induced hippocampal inflammation and neurodegeneration by modulating signaling pathways and Aβ-degrading enzymes.
results_summary: GPE prevented Aβ-induced inflammatory and signaling disruptions, preserved somatostatin functionality, and maintained levels of Aβ-degrading enzymes, suggesting neuroprotective effects against Aβ toxicity.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized rats infused with Aβ25-35.
effective_dosage: 300 pmol/day of Aβ25-35 (GPE dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of chitosan-GSNO nanoparticles and silicon (Si) priming on soybean seed germination and seedling growth, focusing on hormonal regulation.
results_summary: Both chitosan-GSNO nanoparticles (100 µM) and Si (0.5 mM) priming significantly improved seed germination and seedling growth metrics, upregulated GA-related genes, and downregulated ABA-related genes, leading to increased bioactive GA4 levels and reduced ABA content.
population_specificity: Soybean seeds and seedlings.
study_duration: Priming durations ranged from 1-5 hours per concentration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the expression profile, clinical significance, and biological functions of CSRP2 in glioma, and explore its role in mediating the Notch signaling cascade.
results_summary: Increased CSRP2 was associated with unfavorable prognosis in glioma, and its silencing suppressed malignant proliferation, metastasis, and stemness while increasing chemosensitivity. Mechanistically, CSRP2 silencing impaired the Notch signaling cascade, reducing tumor growth in vivo.
population_specificity: Glioma cells and xenograft models in nude mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of glycine on inflammatory responses in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) cell lines, particularly its role in counteracting ethanol-induced inflammation.
results_summary: Glycine attenuated ethanol-induced inflammatory cytokine production in HCC cells, counteracting the pro-inflammatory effects of SLC6A13 overexpression. Elevated SLC6A13 expression, regulated by ASCL1, correlated with improved survival outcomes in HCC.
population_specificity: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the molecular mechanisms underlying cadmium (Cd) accumulation differences between high-Cd-accumulating (HAS) and low-Cd-accumulating (LAS) soybean varieties.
results_summary: The study found that high-Cd-accumulating soybean (HAS) exhibited more differentially expressed genes (DEGs) related to heavy metal transporters and transcription factors after cadmium treatment compared to LAS. Pathway analysis indicated enrichment in glutathione metabolism and plant-pathogen interaction pathways in response to cadmium stress.
population_specificity: Soybean root tissues from two varieties (su8, HAS; su7, LAS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of silica nanoparticles (SiO2 NPs) and potassium silicate on soybean plant growth, physiological traits, and bacterial microbiome responses under salinity stress.
results_summary: The study found that SiO2 NPs treatment enriched beneficial microbial taxa in the leaf and root endospheres, potentially enhancing plant growth and salinity stress resistance, while silicate treatment had a lesser impact on bacterial communities.
population_specificity: 20-day-old soybean plants
effective_dosage: 12 mg of SiO2 per plant, applied every 3 days

study_goal: The researchers aimed to document a rare case of anti-GlyR encephalomyelitis in a renal transplant patient and assess the response to treatment.
results_summary: The study found that a patient with anti-GlyR encephalomyelitis showed significant symptom improvement after corticosteroid and intravenous immunoglobulin treatment, with MRI-confirmed lesion reduction. It highlights GlyR-IgG as a potential diagnostic marker for this rare condition.
population_specificity: A 66-year-old woman who underwent renal transplantation 8 months prior.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of foliar application of amino acids (including Glycine) and zinc on agronomic traits and grain Zn accumulation in soybeans.
results_summary: The study found that foliar application of amino acids and zinc did not affect soybean yield but influenced the number of pods and branches. AA100*Zn6 was the most effective treatment for enhancing Zn biofortification in soybean grains.
population_specificity: Soybean plants under field conditions.
effective_dosage: Amino acids (0, 50, 100, and 150 ml 100 L-1) and zinc (0, 2, 4, and 6 mg L-1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the transporter GmMATE100 in soybean (Glycine max L.) and its role in the transport of soyasaponins between cellular compartments.
results_summary: The study identified GmMATE100 as a transporter for type-A and type-B soyasaponins, showing its co-expression with biosynthetic genes and induction by MeJA, leading to soyasaponin accumulation in roots. Loss-of-function mutants exhibited reduced soyasaponin content, confirming its role in transport.
population_specificity: Soybean (Glycine max L.) plants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify high dry matter-yielding and stable soybean genotypes for forage use in southwestern Ethiopia, evaluating genotype-environment interactions.
results_summary: The study found that dry matter yield was significantly influenced by environment and genotype-environment interaction, with genotype G4 (TGX1990-114FN) being the most stable and high-yielding. Six environments were grouped into four mega-environments, with ENV5 (Kersa 2020) identified as the most discriminating and representative environment.
population_specificity: Soybean genotypes tested in southwestern Ethiopia under rain-fed conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a non-invasive imaging technique using radiolabeled glycine mimics ([18F]FBG) to assess islet function and monitor β cell mass changes in living animals.
results_summary: The study found that [18F]FBG effectively targeted the glycine transporter (GLYT) on islet cells, enabling clear detection of endogenous and exogenous islets in vivo. Pancreatic uptake of [18F]FBG correlated linearly with surviving β cell mass in diabetic mouse models.
population_specificity: Animal models (mice) with streptozocin-induced type 1 diabetes and GLYT over-expressed cells.
effective_dosage: 240–250 nmol of imaging reagent (a mixture of [18F]FBG and natural glycine) intravenously.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the required concentrations and interactions of threonine and glycine (as Gly equivalent) in low-protein diets for broilers to maintain performance without impairing health.
results_summary: The study found that low-protein diets with optimized glycine and threonine levels did not impair broiler performance, with some treatments improving body weight gain, feed conversion ratio, and nitrogen retention efficiency. However, high starch-to-CP ratios negatively affected carcass weight and abdominal fat.
population_specificity: Broiler chickens (11-35 days old)
study_duration: 24 days (grower phase: 11-24 days; finisher phase: 25-35 days)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of manganese glycine (MG) on eggshell quality, elemental deposition, and ultrastructure in aged laying hens.
results_summary: Dietary supplementation with 80 mg/kg Mn from MG improved eggshell strength, altered eggshell ultrastructure, and increased Mn deposition in eggshells, tibia, and yolk compared to manganese sulfate monohydrate (MSM).
population_specificity: 70-week-old Hy-Line Brown laying hens

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the particle size-dependent effects of copper oxide nanoparticles (nCuO) on soybean (Glycine max L.) yield, quality attributes, and oxidative stress biomarkers in a field environment.
results_summary: Smaller nCuO particles (25 nm) showed higher inhibitory effects on photosynthetic pigments, seed yield, and nutrient quality, while increasing Cu bioaccumulation and oxidative stress in soybean. Antioxidant responses increased proportionally with Cu exposure, and TEM analysis revealed altered seed oil bodies and protein storage vacuoles.
population_specificity: Soybean (Glycine max L.) plants grown in a field environment.
effective_dosage: Not specified (three distinct particle sizes of nCuO: 25 nm, 50 nm, 250 nm, compared with CuCl2 and water controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a more efficient method for synthesizing G1M9-glycopeptide (containing Glycine as part of the Asn-Gly-Thr triad) from chicken eggs for studying glycoprotein functions.
results_summary: The study successfully produced 13.2 mg of G1M9-glycopeptide using a modified purification process, improving yield compared to previous methods. The glycopeptide was confirmed via NMR and mass spectroscopy, suggesting potential utility for glycoprotein research.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study using chicken egg-derived materials).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (synthesis study, no dosage tested).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the clinical significance and molecular mechanisms of cysteine- and glycine-rich protein 1 (CSRP1) in acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
results_summary: CSRP1 was highly expressed in AML and associated with poor prognosis. Functional analysis linked CSRP1 to neutrophil activation, apoptosis, and drug resistance patterns in AML.
population_specificity: Patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize conditions for enriching flavonoids in short-germinated black soybeans under slight acid treatment and explore the mechanism of flavonoid accumulation.
results_summary: A slight acid treatment (126.2 mM citric acid-sodium citrate buffer, pH 5.10) significantly increased flavonoid content (2.32 mg/g FW) and key enzyme activities but inhibited soybean growth and caused cellular damage, activating the antioxidant system.
population_specificity: Short-germinated black soybeans

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether glycine inhibits the conversion of aspirin into salicylic acid, potentially reducing adverse effects.
results_summary: The study found that glycine effectively inhibited the conversion of aspirin into salicylic acid, suggesting it may reduce adverse effects associated with aspirin use. The results were confirmed using UV-Visible absorption, fluorescence, and DFT/TD-DFT techniques.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or theoretical study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of β-lactolin-rich whey peptide (containing glycine) on human mood states, stress, and quality of life in healthy adults with relatively low psychological health.
results_summary: β-lactolin supplementation improved trait anxiety, subjective stress, psychological quality of life, and increased salivary immunoglobulin A levels, with notable effects in the 45-54-year-old subgroup.
population_specificity: 60 healthy adults aged 45-64 years with relatively low psychological health.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anatomical basis of GlyT1 inhibition's efficacy in reducing dyskinesia in Parkinson's disease by quantifying GlyT1 levels across different brain regions in parkinsonian rats.
results_summary: The study found decreased [3H]-NFPS binding in the thalamus of rats with severe dyskinesia and increased binding in the substantia nigra, correlating with dyskinesia severity. These changes suggest GlyT1 inhibitors may effectively target specific brain regions to alleviate dyskinesia in Parkinson's disease.
population_specificity: 6-OHDA-lesioned rats (parkinsonian model) exhibiting mild or severe abnormal involuntary movements (AIMs), compared to sham-lesioned and L-DOPA-naïve rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review glycine's anti-inflammatory effects, particularly its modulation of NF-κB expression, and highlight the importance of dietary glycine supplementation in preventing chronic inflammation.
results_summary: Glycine demonstrates anti-inflammatory effects by reducing pro-inflammatory cytokines and free fatty acids, improving insulin response, and modulating NF-κB expression in various cells. The mechanism of action remains unclear, but dietary supplementation is emphasized for preventing chronic inflammation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general organism-level effects discussed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of glycine supplementation on eleven physiological systems in adult humans, focusing on its potential geroprotective benefits.
results_summary: Glycine showed positive effects on the nervous system, improving psychiatric symptoms in psychiatric populations and sleep in healthy populations, though the latter studies had small sample sizes and high risk of bias. Larger, long-term studies are needed to confirm glycine's role in preventing or reversing ageing.
population_specificity: Healthy and diseased adult populations (18 studies on healthy, 34 on diseased).
study_duration: Up to 14 days in healthy populations, up to 4 months in diseased populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the metabolic effects of selenomethionine under different methionine supply conditions, including its impact on glycine levels.
results_summary: Selenomethionine supplementation altered glycine levels, with changes observed regardless of methionine supply. The metabolic disturbance was alleviated with increasing methionine supply, except for glycine and other specific metabolites.
population_specificity: HepG2 cells (a human liver cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a keratin-derived protein (KDP) rich in glycine, cysteine, and arginine on tissue redox status and insulin sensitivity in adults with type-2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The study compared KDP-whey, whey, and a non-protein control in a randomized controlled trial, measuring fasting and insulin-stimulated outcomes, but specific results regarding glycine's effects were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 35 human adults with type-2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of oral l-Carnitine supplementation on moderate-intensity exercise performance.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Glycine's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified in the provided abstract.
effective_dosage: Not mentioned in the provided abstract.
study_duration: Not mentioned in the provided abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the protective effects of nutraceuticals, including Glycine-related pathways (γ-GCL/HO-1 and Nrf-2), against drug-induced hepatotoxicity.
results_summary: The study suggests that nutraceuticals, through mechanisms involving γ-GCL/HO-1 and Nrf-2 pathways, reduce oxidative stress and inflammation, thereby protecting against drug-induced liver injury. Glycine-related enzymes play a role in this antioxidant response.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on drug-induced liver injury mechanisms).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the antidiabetic role of soy protein and peptides in the context of impaired glucose and lipid metabolism, and inflammation.
results_summary: The study found that soy protein and peptides exhibit therapeutic properties in alleviating diabetes and related metabolic complications by modulating cell signaling pathways, improving energy homeostasis, and regulating inflammatory parameters. Clinical intervention studies also noted a correlation between soy protein intake and lower diabetes prevalence.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how glycine influences macrophage polarization and immune cell function.
results_summary: The study found that glycine alters macrophage functions and shapes their polarization, suggesting a role beyond its known inhibitory neurotransmitter effects. Glycine receptors and transporters in macrophages indicate its broader immunomodulatory potential.
population_specificity: Macrophages (in vitro or animal model implied, not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a nutraceutical blend containing Glycine max on skin health and antioxidant status in post-menopausal women.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in skin roughness at week 6 and skin elasticity at week 12, with large effect sizes. Antioxidant status, measured via GSH and MDA levels, also showed positive changes.
population_specificity: Post-menopausal women aged 45-60 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the advantages and disadvantages of folate supplementation with folic acid versus 5-MTHF, focusing on maternal and fetal health, including glycine biosynthesis.
results_summary: The study highlights that 5-MTHF, unlike folic acid, is immediately bioavailable and avoids risks associated with reduced hepatic transformation, supporting its role in metabolic reactions like glycine biosynthesis. However, the abstract does not provide specific results on glycine's effects.
population_specificity: Women in the preconception period and during pregnancy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether the tolerable upper intake level (UL) for glycine in rats could approximate the UL in humans by comparing ratios of NOAEL or LOAEL over usual consumption (UC) and dietary requirement (RQ).
results_summary: The study found that for glycine and eight other amino acids, the calculated ratios of NOAEL or LOAEL over UC and RQ in rats and humans remained within the same order of magnitude, suggesting potential applicability of rat data for human UL estimation.
population_specificity: Rats and humans (indirect comparison via literature review).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on the effects of creatine supplementation (which includes glycine as a component) and physical exercise on oxidative stress.
results_summary: The study suggests that creatine, composed partly of glycine, may enhance antioxidant defense by increasing antioxidant enzyme activity and ROS/RNS elimination, potentially through indirect (energy status) and direct (mitochondrial integrity) mechanisms. The effects may synergize with training, though intensity and duration of exercise influence outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if glycine, alone or combined with tryptophan, could suppress serum uric acid elevation caused by purine ingestion and enhance urinary uric acid excretion in individuals with lower urate excretion.
results_summary: Combined glycine and tryptophan supplementation significantly reduced elevated serum uric acid levels post-purine ingestion. Glycine alone and in combination increased urinary uric acid excretion and urate clearance, with urinary pH also rising, suggesting improved uric acid solubility.
population_specificity: Healthy Japanese adult males with lower urate excretion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the postprandial bile acid response in plasma and its relation to insulin, GLP-1, and FGF19, specifically after administering glycine-conjugated deoxycholic acid (gDCA) with a meal.
results_summary: The study examined the postprandial response to a 40-hour fast and the effects of gDCA administration with a meal, but the abstract does not provide specific results regarding Glycine's effects.
population_specificity: Healthy, lean men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent advances in glycine metabolism, identify causes of glycine deficiency in obesity-related metabolic disorders, and evaluate the potential benefits of glycine supplementation.
results_summary: Lower glycine levels were consistently observed in obesity, T2DM, and NAFLD, with clinical studies suggesting beneficial effects from glycine supplementation in these conditions. The study highlights the role of diet, gut microbiota, and liver metabolism in glycine availability.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity, type 2 diabetes, and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.

study_goal: The researchers investigated the effects of colonic propionate delivery (via IPE and inulin) on glucose homeostasis, plasma metabolome (including glycine), gut bacteria, and inflammation.
results_summary: Fasting insulin was negatively associated with plasma glycine following inulin supplementation, suggesting a potential role of glycine in metabolic improvements. However, glycine-specific effects were not the primary focus of the study.
population_specificity: Twelve non-diabetic adults with overweight and obesity.
effective_dosage: Not specified for glycine (study used 20 g/day of inulin-propionate ester, inulin, or cellulose).

study_goal: The study aimed to define formate concentrations and their determinants in a healthy young population, including examining associations with glycine.
results_summary: The study found that formate concentrations were positively associated with potential metabolic precursors (serine, methionine, tryptophan, choline) but not with glycine.
population_specificity: Healthy men and women aged 18 to 28 years enrolled at Trinity College, Dublin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the serum uric acid-lowering effects of combined glycine and tryptophan supplementation in patients with mild hyperuricemia.
results_summary: Combined supplementation with glycine and tryptophan significantly decreased serum uric acid levels from 7.1 mg/dL to 6.7 mg/dL over 6 weeks.
population_specificity: Japanese healthy adult males and females with mild hyperuricemia (fasting serum uric acid of 6.6⁻7.9 mg/dL).
effective_dosage: 3.0 g glycine and 0.2 g tryptophan once daily at bedtime.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in cyclic glycine-proline (cGP) and IGF-1 levels in Parkinson's disease patients after supplementation with blackcurrant anthocyanins (BCA), which contains cGP.
results_summary: BCA supplementation increased cGP concentrations in plasma and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), suggesting potential neuroprotective effects through improved IGF-1 function in Parkinson's disease patients.
population_specificity: 11 male Parkinson's disease patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of glycine supplementation on mitigating negative protein balance during weight loss in aging individuals with chronic low-grade metabolic acidosis.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding glycine's effects, only stating the study's objective.
population_specificity: Aging individuals with chronic low-grade metabolic acidosis undergoing weight loss.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the clinical and biochemical characteristics, diagnostic approaches, and treatment strategies for organic acidurias (OADs), including the role of glycine esters in metabolic dysfunction.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that glycine esters of organic acids may accumulate in OADs and contribute to toxicity, but it does not specifically evaluate glycine supplementation or its effects.
population_specificity: Individuals with organic acidurias (OADs), including newborns and patients with acute metabolic crises.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of guanidinoacetic acid (GAA) as an alternative to creatine for improving brain creatine levels in patients with AGAT deficiency.
results_summary: The study suggests that GAA may be a viable alternative to creatine for restoring brain creatine levels in AGAT deficiency, with potential benefits in bioavailability and utilization, but notes possible drawbacks such as neurotoxicity and hyperhomocysteinemia.
population_specificity: Patients with arginine-glycine amidinotransferase (AGAT) deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review glycine metabolism in humans and animals and its beneficial effects in various disease states.
results_summary: Glycine is effective in improving health, supporting growth, and preventing diseases such as cancer, cardiovascular diseases, inflammatory diseases, obesity, and diabetes. It also enhances sleep quality and neurological functions.
population_specificity: Humans, animals, and birds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the absorption, metabolism, and potential biological effects of (poly)phenols, including their glycine conjugates, in humans.
results_summary: The study found that (poly)phenols are metabolized into various forms, including glycine conjugates, which are absorbed and appear in plasma. Some catabolites reached concentrations in plasma that may be biologically effective, suggesting potential in vivo benefits.
population_specificity: Human volunteers (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of vitamin B6, including its involvement in glycine metabolism, in inflammatory conditions and chronic diseases.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin B6, including its role in glycine metabolism, is linked to reduced inflammatory markers and improved immune functions, particularly in deficient individuals. It also suggested that vitamin B6 may be mobilized to inflammation sites to support immunomodulating pathways.
population_specificity: Humans and experimental animals with inflammatory conditions or vitamin B6 deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide consensus recommendations for the diagnosis and management of methylation disorders, including glycine N-methyltransferase deficiency, based on literature review and clinical evaluation.
results_summary: The study found that methylation disorders, including glycine N-methyltransferase deficiency, predominantly affect the liver, central nervous system, and muscles, with varying clinical presentations. Plasma S-adenosylmethionine and S-adenosylhomocysteine are key diagnostic metabolites, and dietary or supplementation interventions may be beneficial in some cases.
population_specificity: Patients with inherited methylation disorders, including glycine N-methyltransferase deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of high-dose antithrombin supplementation (using a placebo containing 1% glycine) in patients with early preeclampsia.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in fetal/neonatal outcomes with high-dose antithrombin, though maternal benefits like reduced blood loss and improved lab markers were observed. The trial was underpowered, limiting definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with single pregnancies and preeclampsia occurring before 30 weeks of gestation.
effective_dosage: Placebo contained 1% glycine (exact dosage not specified).
study_duration: Up to 7 days or until delivery, whichever came first.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of glycine as a substrate for creatine synthesis and its implications for dietary creatine availability in different populations.
results_summary: The study found that glycine, along with arginine and methionine, is essential for creatine synthesis. It noted that vegetarians and infants on soy-based formulas may have lower creatine levels due to lack of dietary creatine, which is derived from glycine and other amino acids.
population_specificity: Humans, including omnivores, vegetarians, and infants, as well as carnivorous animals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of glycine and other nutrients in epigenetic modifications related to metabolic syndrome and transgenerational health outcomes.
results_summary: The study suggests glycine plays a key role in providing methyl donors for DNA and protein methylation, which may help regulate metabolic pathways affected by maternal malnutrition. Dietary supplementation with glycine and related nutrients could potentially improve health outcomes in offspring by targeting epigenetically disturbed pathways.
population_specificity: Human and animal models (focus on maternal and fetal health).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of dietary supplementation with energy and protein, including glycine, on pregnancy outcomes, protein kinetics, and methyl group donor fluxes in low-BMI Indian women.
results_summary: The study found that supplementation with energy and protein, including glycine, had no significant effect on pregnancy outcomes, whole-body protein kinetics, or serine and glycine fluxes, except for minor changes in leucine flux and nonoxidative disposal.
population_specificity: Pregnant Indian women aged 22.9 ± 0.7 years with low BMIs (≤18.5 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 300 kcal/day, 15 g protein/day (specific glycine dosage not specified).
study_duration: From 12 ± 1 weeks of gestation to delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of glycine in creatine synthesis, its metabolic effects, and potential benefits in conditions like fatty liver disease and neuroprotection.
results_summary: The study found that glycine-derived creatine synthesis plays a key role in energy buffering, reduces fat accumulation in the liver, and may offer neuroprotective effects. However, potential adverse effects like oxidative stress and carcinogenic compound formation were noted as understudied.
population_specificity: Not specified (general metabolic and neurological contexts implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of adjunct S-adenosyl methionine to enhance intracerebral creatine synthesis in patients with creatine transporter deficiency, who were already on high-dose oral creatine, glycine, and L-arginine supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that while no increase in intracerebral creatine was observed, significant improvements in speech/language skills, muscle mass, and personal outcomes were noted in one patient. However, behavioral and sleep issues were reported at higher doses of S-adenosyl methionine.
population_specificity: Male patients with creatine transporter (SLC6A8) deficiency, including an 8-year-old male.
effective_dosage: High-dose oral creatine, glycine, and L-arginine supplementation (specific dosage not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the carcinogenic potential of glyphosate, an herbicidal derivative of glycine, based on toxicological and epidemiological data.
results_summary: The study found no evidence of a carcinogenic effect related to glyphosate treatment, supported by a lack of plausible mechanism, consistent epidemiological data, and a weight of evidence evaluation.
population_specificity: Not specified (regulatory and toxicological data, likely animal models and human epidemiological studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the current literature on homoarginine (hArg) in renal and cardiovascular systems, including its potential role in arginine metabolism and energy pathways involving glycine.
results_summary: Low hArg levels were identified as an independent risk marker for cardiovascular, cerebrovascular, and renal diseases, with potential involvement in nitric oxide synthesis and energy metabolism via AGAT, an enzyme linked to glycine metabolism. The therapeutic potential of hArg supplementation or AGAT modulation remains unclear.
population_specificity: General discussion of epidemiological studies; no specific population mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of vitamin B-6 supplementation on one-carbon and tryptophan metabolism, including glycine levels, in vitamin B-6-deficient oral contraceptive users.
results_summary: Vitamin B-6 supplementation significantly reduced glycine concentrations (from 317 ± 63 to 267 ± 58 nmol/L) and altered metabolic profiles, suggesting functional vitamin B-6 deficiency, but did not affect homocysteine remethylation or cystathionine production.
population_specificity: Women aged 20-40 years using oral contraceptives with low plasma PLP concentrations (<30 nmol/L).
effective_dosage: 10 mg pyridoxine hydrochloric acid per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to collect data on adverse effects, misidentification, and interactions related to plant food supplements, including Glycine max/soybean.
results_summary: Glycine max/soybean was among the top plants associated with adverse effects, accounting for 19.3% of the total references. However, the overall frequency of adverse effects was relatively low, with severe reactions being very limited.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human population based on literature review).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of glycine in treating cerebral creatine deficiencies (CDD), specifically in AGAT and SLC6A8 deficiencies, as part of broader therapeutic strategies.
results_summary: Glycine supplementation, alongside arginine, was used to support intracerebral creatine synthesis in SLC6A8 deficiency, with early recognition and treatment improving outcomes. Normal outcomes in neonatally treated siblings suggest potential benefits of early intervention.
population_specificity: Patients with cerebral creatine deficiencies (AGAT, GAMT, SLC6A8 deficiencies), particularly those with intellectual developmental disorders and related symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if parenteral cysteine supplementation compared to isonitrogenous noncysteine supplementation increases erythrocyte reduced glutathione (GSH) in critically ill neonates at risk for inflammatory injury.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in erythrocyte GSH concentrations between the cysteine and control groups, but the cysteine group showed a larger individual positive change in GSH. Smaller infants and those receiving blood transfusions had less effective changes in GSH with cysteine supplementation.
population_specificity: Critically ill neonates with a score for neonatal acute physiology >10 requiring mechanical ventilation and parenteral nutrition.
effective_dosage: 121 mg/kg/d of parenteral cysteine-HCl or isonitrogenous noncysteine supplementation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of oral glutathione (GSH) supplementation, which contains glycine, on human blood GSH levels.
results_summary: The study found no significant change in GSH levels in the deproteinized plasma or blood cell fractions after GSH ingestion, but a significant increase in the protein-bound plasma fraction from 60 to 120 minutes post-supplementation.
population_specificity: Healthy human volunteers
study_duration: Single dose, effects measured up to 120 minutes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of glycine, alone or in combination with creatine and arginine, in treating creatine transporter deficiency (CTD) by assessing clinical and biochemical outcomes.
results_summary: Glycine, when combined with creatine and arginine, showed clinical improvement in 36% of CTD patients, particularly those with residual brain creatine and early treatment initiation. Increased cerebral creatine post-treatment correlated with clinical improvement.
population_specificity: Patients with creatine transporter deficiency (CTD), primarily children with intellectual disability, behavioral disturbances, and seizures.
effective_dosage: Not specified (used in combination with creatine-monohydrate and L-arginine).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if glycine supplementation, alongside cysteine, could correct glutathione (GSH) deficiency and improve mitochondrial fuel oxidation in older HIV-infected patients.
results_summary: Glycine and cysteine supplementation restored GSH synthesis, improved mitochondrial fat and carbohydrate oxidation, and enhanced insulin sensitivity, body composition, and muscle strength in the studied patients.
population_specificity: Older GSH-deficient HIV-infected males

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of daily glycine supplementation on antioxidant enzymes and lipid peroxidation in patients with metabolic syndrome (MetS).
results_summary: Glycine supplementation reduced TBARS by 25% and SOD-specific activity by 20%, while increasing G6PD activity and SNO-Hb levels in males. It also significantly lowered systolic blood pressure in glycine-treated men.
population_specificity: 60 volunteers with metabolic syndrome (30 glycine-treated, 30 placebo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between homoarginine (linked to glycine metabolism via AGAT) and outcomes after ischemic stroke.
results_summary: Higher homoarginine levels were associated with reduced mortality and improved outcomes in ischemic stroke patients, and AGAT-related genetic modulation in mice supported a protective role for homoarginine in stroke pathology.
population_specificity: Human patients with ischemic stroke and murine models (AGAT(-/-) and GAMT(-/-) mice).
study_duration: 7.4 years of follow-up in humans; murine study duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of soybean leaf extracts (SLEs) and banaba extracts (BE) on blood glucose, insulin resistance, body fat, and dyslipidemia in prediabetes subjects.
results_summary: SLE significantly improved blood glucose, insulin resistance, body fat, and dyslipidemia, similar to or better than BE, including increased HDL-cholesterol and reduced atherogenic index. No significant changes were observed in body weight, BMI, or WHR between groups.
population_specificity: Overweight subjects with mild hyperglycemia (fasting blood glucose 100-125 mg/dL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether GAKIC supplementation enhances performance during multiple bouts of resistance exercise.
results_summary: GAKIC significantly increased total load volume during leg-press exercises compared to placebo, but no significant differences were observed in heart rate, blood lactate, one-repetition maximum, or blood glucose between GAKIC and placebo.
population_specificity: Seven resistance-trained men.
study_duration: One week (crossover design with two testing sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether GAKIC supplementation improves resistance performance and metabolic parameters in college-age females during repeated bouts of submaximal leg extensions.
results_summary: GAKIC significantly increased total load volume during leg extensions compared to placebo, but did not significantly affect heart rate, blood lactic acid, or blood glucose levels post-exercise. The findings suggest GAKIC enhances lower body resistance performance in trained females, though generalizability is limited.
population_specificity: Resistance-trained, college-age females
study_duration: Single-dose intervention (two sessions, one week apart)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of glycine and other nutrients in epigenetic mechanisms related to fetal programming of metabolic diseases.
results_summary: The study highlights glycine's role in providing methyl donors for DNA and protein methylation, which is crucial for epigenetic regulation, but does not provide specific efficacy data on glycine alone.
population_specificity: General discussion on maternal nutrition and offspring metabolic health, not specific to a defined population.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the tolerability and incidence of adverse effects of various oral iron supplements, including ferrous glycine sulfate.
results_summary: Ferrous glycine sulfate had a higher incidence of overall adverse effects (23.5%) and gastrointestinal adverse effects (18.5%) compared to the reference supplement (ferrous sulfate with mucoproteose), with an odds ratio of 5.90 for adverse effects. The differences in tolerability were statistically significant (p < 0.001).
population_specificity: 10,695 patients from 111 clinical or observational studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if glutathione deficiency in aging is due to reduced synthesis and whether supplementation with glycine and cysteine could restore glutathione levels and reduce oxidative stress.
results_summary: Elderly subjects had significantly lower glutathione levels and higher oxidative stress compared to younger subjects. Supplementation with glycine and cysteine restored glutathione synthesis, reduced oxidative stress, and normalized levels to those of younger subjects.
population_specificity: Elderly and younger human subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether GAKIC supplementation reduces fatigue during high-intensity, repeated cycle sprints in trained cyclists.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in peak power, mean power, fatigue index, heart rate, or perceived exertion between GAKIC and placebo groups, suggesting GAKIC had no ergogenic effect in trained individuals.
population_specificity: Well-trained male cyclists
effective_dosage: 11.2 g of GAKIC administered once before the trial

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of creatine and its synthesizing enzymes, including glycine, in tumor regression and the augmentation of methylglyoxal's anticancer effects.
results_summary: The study found that creatine supplementation significantly enhanced the anticancer effects of methylglyoxal and ascorbic acid, leading to tumor regression and elevated creatine levels in sarcoma tissue. Creatine-synthesizing enzymes were prominently expressed in malignant cells but undetectable in skeletal muscle.
population_specificity: Sarcoma, Ehrlich ascites carcinoma, and sarcoma 180 cells (animal or cell line models, not specified for humans).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of glycine in creatine deficiency syndromes, focusing on its diagnostic and therapeutic implications.
results_summary: The study found that glycine-related deficiencies (L-arginine-glycine amidinotransferase and guanidinoacetate methyltransferase) contribute to creatine depletion in the brain, leading to mental retardation, speech delay, and epilepsy. Oral creatine supplementation was effective for some deficiencies but not for creatine transporter deficiency.
population_specificity: Children with unexplained mental retardation, seizures, and speech delay.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether GlyNAC, alone or combined with body weight support treadmill training (BWSTT), could improve motor function recovery and delay skeletal muscle atrophy in rats with spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: GlyNAC alone improved motor function (BBB scores, gait symmetry, open field test results) and skeletal muscle structure/function (CSA, grip strength, AChE immunostaining). Combining GlyNAC with BWSTT was more effective than either treatment alone for motor function recovery.
population_specificity: Rats with spinal cord injury (SCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether carvacrol (CVR) could control Alternaria rot on goji berries and reduce mycotoxin production by Alternaria alternata.
results_summary: CVR showed strong antifungal activity against A. alternata, with a minimum inhibitory concentration of 0.12 µL/mL, and significantly reduced mycotoxin accumulation. It also caused plasma membrane damage, oxidative stress, and altered gene expression related to metabolism and antioxidant enzymes in the fungus.
population_specificity: Alternaria alternata (fungus affecting goji berries)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the active ingredients, pharmacological activities, signaling pathways, and gut microbiota impact of Lycium varieties (Goji berries), as well as their potential in treating COVID-19.
results_summary: The study found that Goji berries exhibit anti-aging, antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and anti-exercise fatigue effects, with distinct chemical compositions (carotenoids and anthocyanins) among varieties. The review also highlights their potential therapeutic targets for chronic diseases and metabolic disorders.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human health focus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of Goji Berry supplementation on reproductive and productive performances, immune system, metabolic homeostasis, and meat quality in livestock, particularly rabbits.
results_summary: The study found that Goji Berries exhibit beneficial properties such as anti-aging, antioxidant, anticancer, neuroprotective, cytoprotective, antidiabetic, and anti-inflammatory activities, with encouraging results in livestock, though optimal dosage and sustainability require further research.
population_specificity: Livestock animals, primarily rabbits, with some references to other species.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether carbon dot-mediated photodynamic treatment (CD-mediated PDT) could improve the storage time and quality attributes of post-harvest goji berries by regulating the antioxidant system.
results_summary: CD-mediated PDT extended the storage time of goji berries by 9 days, delayed hardness and decay index loss, reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA, H2O2, O2•-), preserved vital nutrients (total protein, phenols, flavonoids), and enhanced antioxidant enzyme activities (CAT, APX, POD, PAL, GR, SOD). It also induced the accumulation of ascorbic acid (ASA) and glutathione (GSH).
population_specificity: Post-harvest goji berries

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize and compare phenolic compounds in four Lycium fruit species and evaluate their inhibitory activity against 5α-reductase for potential benefits in preventing and treating Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH).
results_summary: The study identified 63 phenolics across four Lycium species, with nine being common and predominant. Phenolic extracts from Lycium barbarum L. (LBL) showed the highest inhibitory activity against 5α-reductase, while two other species showed no activity, potentially due to differences in marker compound concentrations.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate a potential herb-drug interaction between Goji Berries and flecainide, leading to toxicity in a patient using GB for COVID-19 prevention.
results_summary: The study reported a case of flecainide toxicity in a patient consuming Goji Berry tea, likely due to CYP2D6 inhibition, which affected flecainide metabolism. The patient recovered after treatment.
population_specificity: A 75-year-old female with atrial extrasystoles using flecainide and Goji Berry tea.
interactions: Interaction with flecainide via CYP2D6 inhibition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the storability of fresh goji berries treated with high CO2 and low O2 concentrations before air storage at 1 °C for 21 days.
results_summary: Controlled atmosphere treatments (5+15 and 20+20) reduced weight loss and prevented fungal decay without affecting most quality parameters. Panelists rated CA-treated samples as sweet with good acceptance after 14 days of storage.
population_specificity: Fresh goji berries (Lycium barbarum L.) harvested without stems.
effective_dosage: Not specified (controlled atmosphere treatments: 21% O2 + 0% CO2, 5% O2 + 15% CO2, 10% O2 + 10% CO2, 20% O2 + 20% CO2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the bioaccessibility of trace metals (copper, zinc, manganese) in Goji Berries and identify compounds responsible for their high bioaccessibility.
results_summary: Goji Berries contained high levels of trace metals (Zn: 10.6μgg-1, Mn: 9.9μgg-1, Cu: 6.1μgg-1), which were highly bioaccessible (56-72% in gastric extract, 23-35% in gastrointestinal extract). Ionic liquid and pectinase extraction efficiently identified metal complexes likely responsible for improved bioaccessibility.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how raw material (dried vs. fresh goji berries), pressing treatment, and glycosidase application affect the aromatic profile of goji berry wine.
results_summary: Dried goji berry fermented wine had stronger fruity, floral, caramel, and herbaceous odors due to higher levels of specific compounds, while fresh berry fermented wine exhibited stronger chemical notes. Pressing reduced fruity and caramel odors, and glycosidase addition did not alter aromatic composition.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on wine production, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review efficacy data for Gotu Kola and other neuroactive botanicals in improving cognitive function, stress reduction, memory, mood, attention, concentration, focus, and alertness.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings for Gotu Kola, only mentioning it as one of the botanicals reviewed for cognitive and brain health benefits.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of cyclodextrins (β-CD and HP-β-CD) on preserving antioxidant compounds, vitamin C, retinol equivalents, and sensory properties in mandarin juices enriched with pomegranate extract and goji berry juice.
results_summary: The study found that HP-β-CD addition resulted in lower losses of vitamin C and retinol equivalents, better color retention, higher antioxidant capacity, and improved sensory quality compared to β-CD and control juices. HP-β-CD-treated juices maintained superior quality after 30 days of cold storage.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or food product study, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the chemical composition, nutritional values, and health benefits of Gotu Kola to emphasize its traditional use as food and medicine.
results_summary: The study highlights Gotu Kola's high medicinal triterpenoids, beneficial carotenoids, and other nutrients, with in vitro and in vivo studies showing antidiabetic, wound-healing, antimicrobial, memory-enhancing, antioxidant, and neuroprotective effects, though clinical trial data is limited.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review, no specific population studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the utility of HIIT for improving health-related fitness in adolescents and identify potential moderators of training effects.
results_summary: HIIT showed large effects on cardiorespiratory fitness and medium effects on body composition, with study duration moderating body fat percentage changes. Effects on waist circumference and muscular fitness were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 13-18 years

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare different support strategies for weight management, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), as part of a broader lifestyle intervention.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results for HIIT, as the study focuses on comparing support strategies rather than directly evaluating HIIT's effects.
population_specificity: Overweight adults (BMI ≥ 27)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate enjoyment levels of overweight and obese subjects undergoing 3 weeks of high-intensity interval training.
results_summary: The study assessed enjoyment levels in overweight and obese individuals after 3 weeks of high-intensity interval training, but specific results on enjoyment were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Generally healthy overweight and obese men and women (BMI = 30.8 ± 4.8 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a 14-week HIIT intervention with weight stability on metabolic flexibility, insulin sensitivity, and cardiorespiratory fitness in sedentary, overweight/obese African American women.
results_summary: HIIT improved exercise tolerance and fat oxidation but did not significantly enhance insulin sensitivity, metabolic flexibility, or postabsorptive fat oxidation compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Sedentary, premenopausal, nondiabetic, overweight/obese African American women.
effective_dosage: Three sessions per week of four high-intensity cycling intervals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of modified high-intensity interval training (HIIT) on liver fat, cardiac function, and metabolic control in adults with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: HIIT reduced liver fat, whole-body fat mass, and liver enzyme levels (alanine and aspartate aminotransferase) while improving early diastolic filling rate, but showed no significant effect on glucose control compared to standard care.
population_specificity: Adults with NAFLD (age 54±10 years, BMI 31±4 kg/m², intra-hepatic lipid >5%).
effective_dosage: Thrice weekly cycle ergometry for 30-40 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of HIIT versus MICT on metabolic risk factors and assess whether a subsequent low-calorie diet intervention influenced these outcomes.
results_summary: HIIT improved VO2peak more than MICT during the exercise intervention, but this advantage disappeared after detraining. Both HIIT and MICT followed by a low-calorie diet positively affected metabolic risk factors.
population_specificity: 26 male workers with metabolic risk factors (average age 47.4 ± 7.1 years, VO2peak 28.5 ± 3.9 ml/kg/min).
effective_dosage: HIIT: 3 sets of 3-min cycling with 2-min active rest between sets, 3 times/week (180 kcal/session).
study_duration: 8-week exercise intervention followed by a 4-week low-calorie diet intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIT) on haematological adaptations (total haemoglobin mass, blood volume, plasma volume) and VO2max in well-trained athletes.
results_summary: The study found that 11 HIT sessions did not significantly improve haematological parameters (tHb-mass, BV, PV) compared to the control group, but VO2max improved by 3.5% within the HIT group. The HIT group also showed a significant reduction in HRmax and an increase in oxygen pulse.
population_specificity: Well-trained male and female athletes (VO2max 63.7 ± 7.7 ml/min/kg).
effective_dosage: Four 4-minute interval bouts at 90-95% of HRmax, separated by 4-minute active recovery periods, performed in 11 sessions over 3 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the subjective affective responses and effectiveness of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIT) versus Moderate-Intensity Continuous Training (MIT) in improving aerobic fitness in sedentary middle-aged men.
results_summary: HIT was found to be equally effective as MIT in improving aerobic fitness, but it induced higher perceived exertion, negative emotions, and stress during sessions. However, displeasure lessened over time, suggesting similar mental adaptations for both training modes.
population_specificity: Sedentary middle-aged men (mean age 47 ± 5 years, mean VO2peak 34.2 ± 4.1 mL·kg⁻¹·min⁻¹).
effective_dosage: HIT: 4-6 × 30-second all-out cycling efforts at ~180% of peak workload with 4-minute recovery; MIT: 40-60 minutes continuous cycling at 60% of peak workload.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if 10 weeks of HIIT at 85-95% of HRmax improves CVD risk factors in rheumatic patients and if these patients tolerate such high-intensity exercise.
results_summary: HIIT increased VO2max by 12.2% and improved heart rate recovery by 2.9%, while reducing BMI, body fat, and waist circumference. No changes in disease activity or pain were detected, indicating good tolerance.
population_specificity: Women aged 20-50 with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) or adult-onset juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).
effective_dosage: 4 × 4 min intervals at 85-95% of HRmax, twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare adherence rates and cardiometabolic outcomes between HIIT and moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) in individuals with prediabetes over a short-term follow-up period.
results_summary: HIIT showed higher adherence (89% vs. 71%) and greater minutes of vigorous physical activity (24 vs. 11 minutes/week) compared to MICT. Both groups equally improved cardiorespiratory fitness and systolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: Individuals with prediabetes (n = 32, HIIT = 15, MICT = 17).
effective_dosage: HIIT or MICT performed three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether short-term high-intensity interval training (HIIT) induces detectable morphological cardiac changes in previously untrained men using cardiovascular magnetic resonance imaging.
results_summary: Sixteen weeks of HIIT led to significant increases in left and right ventricular volume and mass, correlated with improved maximal aerobic capacity and reduced blood lactate concentration at the anaerobic threshold. The study found no late gadolinium enhancement, indicating balanced cardiac adaptation without adverse structural changes.
population_specificity: Previously untrained men (average age ~43 years).
effective_dosage: Interval runs at 95%-105% of individually calculated heart rate at the anaerobic threshold.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to illustrate a rigorous quantitative evaluation of intervention fidelity for a high-intensity interval training program in adolescents.
results_summary: The study found that 58% of repetitions met the high-intensity criterion in the intention-to-treat analysis, increasing to 68% in the per-protocol analysis. Mean peak heart rates were 85% and 91% of maximal, respectively, with significant variability between and within subjects.
population_specificity: Seventeen adolescents (mean age 14.0 ± 0.3 years).
effective_dosage: Two sessions per week, each consisting of 4-7 repetitions of 45-s maximal effort with 90-s rest.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increasing high-intensity interval training (HIT) at the expense of total training volume affects stress and recovery levels in elite swimmers.
results_summary: After 12 weeks, the HIT group showed a 16.6% lower general stress level and a 6.5% higher general recovery level compared to the control group, though no significant changes were observed in sports-specific stress or recovery.
population_specificity: Elite swimmers (41 participants, 30 completed questionnaires).
effective_dosage: ~5 hours of HIT per week (6-10 × 10-30 s maximal effort intervals with 2-4 min rest).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) versus continued moderate training (CON) on vascular function, biomarkers, and health-related quality of life in heart transplant recipients.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved VO(2peak) and physical component scores of HRQoL, and reduced depression scores more than CON. Both HIIT and CON reduced anxiety scores, but neither significantly affected vascular function or biomarkers.
population_specificity: Stable heart transplant recipients >12 months post-transplantation (mean age 52 years, 75% male).
study_duration: 12 weeks per intervention (HIIT or CON), followed by a 5-month washout and crossover.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether restricting carbohydrate intake between twice-daily HIIT sessions enhances exercise performance and mitochondrial content compared to higher carbohydrate intake.
results_summary: The study found that the group with restricted carbohydrate intake (HI-LO) showed greater improvement in 250-kJ time trial performance compared to the high-carbohydrate group (HI-HI), though mitochondrial content increases were similar between groups. This suggests short-term "train low, compete high" interventions may improve whole-body exercise capacity.
population_specificity: Eighteen active but not highly trained subjects (VO2peak = 44 ± 9 ml/kg/min), matched for age, sex, and fitness.
effective_dosage: HI-HI group: ~2.3 g/kg CHO (195 g total); HI-LO group: ~0.3 g/kg CHO (17 g total), ingested during the 3-hour period between sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and quantify the impact of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) compared to Moderate-Intensity Continuous Training (MICT) on vascular function.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved brachial artery flow-mediated dilation (FMD) by 4.31% compared to 2.15% for MICT, with a mean difference of 2.26%. HIIT also showed greater positive effects on cardiorespiratory fitness, cardiovascular disease risk factors, oxidative stress, inflammation, and insulin sensitivity.
population_specificity: 182 patients from seven randomized trials.
effective_dosage: Four intervals of 4 minutes at 85-95% of maximum/peak heart rate, interspersed with 3 minutes of active recovery at 60-70% of maximum/peak heart rate, three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) versus Moderate Intensity Continuous Training (MIT) in improving cardiorespiratory fitness markers in coronary heart disease (CHD) patients.
results_summary: HIIT improved the oxygen pulse (O2P) slope significantly more than MIT, while both training regimens similarly improved ventilation-carbon dioxide production (VE/VCO2 slope) and oxygen uptake efficiency slope (OUES) compared to controls. No significant differences were found between HIIT and MIT for VE/VCO2 slope or OUES.
population_specificity: Coronary heart disease (CHD) patients with optimized treatment (n=71, ages 56-64).
effective_dosage: HIIT: 30-minute sessions split into 2-minute alternate bouts at 60%/90% of maximal heart rate, 3 times/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of two HIIT protocols, varying in intensity and interval duration, on clinical outcomes in overweight/obese men.
results_summary: HIIT did not significantly affect fat mass or body fat percentage but showed non-significant increases in lean mass and VO2peak. Insulin sensitivity improved significantly in both training groups compared to controls.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese men (BMI > 25 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 1MIN-HIIT: 10 × 1 min bouts at 90% power output with 1 min rests; 2MIN-HIIT: 5 × 2 min bouts at undulating intensities (80%-100%) with 1 min rests, 3 days/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess long-term exercise adherence and changes in peak oxygen uptake following a high-intensity interval training (HIT) cardiac rehabilitation programme, comparing home-based and hospital-based approaches.
results_summary: The study found that both home-based and hospital-based HIT maintained significantly elevated peak oxygen uptake levels at one-year follow-up, with over 90% of participants meeting recommended daily physical activity levels. The home-based group showed a trend toward increased physical activity compared to hospital-based groups.
population_specificity: Adults (68 men, 8 women; mean age 59) who had previously attended a 12-week HIT cardiac rehabilitation programme for coronary artery disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIT) and supramaximal interval training (SMIT) on indoor rowing performance and related physiological variables in collegiate rowers.
results_summary: Both SMIT and HIT significantly improved 2,000-m rowing performance, power output, and VO2peak, with no significant differences between the two training methods. The improvements were modest but consistent across measured outcomes.
population_specificity: 20 male lightweight collegiate rowers (age 21.77 ± 2.35 years).
effective_dosage: SMIT: 10 × 30-second intervals at 150% PPO, 4-minute rest, 2x/week; HIT: 8 × 2.5-minute intervals at 90% PPO, 3-minute rest, 2x/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the prognostic and symptomatic benefits of exercise training, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), in various cardiovascular diseases.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT may achieve superior improvements in aerobic exercise capacity and muscle mass, though its prognostic value still needs further determination. It also highlighted benefits in conditions like heart failure with preserved ejection fraction and pulmonary hypertension.
population_specificity: Patients with cardiovascular diseases, including stable coronary artery disease, heart failure (reduced and preserved ejection fraction), pulmonary hypertension, and valvular heart disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of 10-20-30 high-intensity interval training on performance, blood pressure, and skeletal muscle angiogenesis in recreational runners, as well as its feasibility in local running communities.
results_summary: The 10-20-30 training improved 5-km run time by 38 seconds, lowered systolic blood pressure (especially in hypertensive subjects), and increased VO2max, but did not affect muscle morphology and reduced muscle VEGF expression. No changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Recreational runners (160 participants, with a subgroup of 18 for muscle biopsies).
effective_dosage: Two of three weekly training sessions replaced with 10-20-30 training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) could improve postprandial glucose control in individuals with or at risk for type 2 diabetes (T2D).
results_summary: The study found that HIIT may be particularly effective for improving postprandial hyperglycemia, which is a significant risk factor for cardiovascular morbidity and mortality in individuals with or at risk for T2D. The findings highlight HIIT's potential application in preventing and managing T2D and associated cardiovascular complications.
population_specificity: Individuals with or at risk for type 2 diabetes (T2D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cardiovascular protective effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) in hypertensive individuals and compare its efficacy with other exercise modalities.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT appears to have strong cardiovascular protective effects, though data in hypertensive individuals is limited. The benefits of regular exercise, including HIIT, far outweigh the risks, with rare cardiovascular events associated with exercise.
population_specificity: Hypertensive individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding high-intensity interval training (HIIT) to a traditional judo program improves physiologic and performance metrics in elite judokas.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT improved maximal speed, ventilatory threshold, and recovery kinetics (HR and V̇O2), while V̇O2max remained unchanged. The Special Judo Fitness Test (SJFT) Index also showed significant improvement.
population_specificity: Nine elite judokas (6 males, 3 females; age 20±4 years; 13±6 years of judo practice).
effective_dosage: 2 sessions/week of 30-min continuous run at 60% Vmax and 1 session/week of HIIT (15x1-min at 90% Vmax with 1-min active recovery at 60% Vmax).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence for incorporating aerobic exercise, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), into stroke rehabilitation and provide guidance on exercise prescription using the FITT principle.
results_summary: The study highlights that HIIT has shown early but promising results for achieving higher target heart rates in stroke survivors, potentially improving cardiovascular health and functional capacity. However, the abstract does not provide detailed quantitative outcomes or statistical significance.
population_specificity: People after stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a 12-month maintenance program involving supervised high-intensity interval training could improve exercise adherence and peak oxygen uptake in CAD patients post-cardiac rehabilitation compared to usual care.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in peak oxygen uptake, physical activity levels, quality of life, or blood biomarkers in CAD patients after 12 months of the maintenance program compared to usual care. Infrequent supervised high-intensity interval training sessions were deemed inadequate for improving peak oxygen uptake in this patient group.
population_specificity: Patients with coronary artery disease (CAD) on optimal medical treatment, recently discharged from cardiac rehabilitation (49 participants, 15 women).
effective_dosage: One monthly supervised high-intensity interval training session, plus a written exercise program and diary, with a maximum exercise test every third month.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) versus moderate-intensity aerobic continuous training (MI-ACT) on peak oxygen uptake, left ventricular diastolic dysfunction, and endothelial function in patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved peak oxygen uptake (V̇o₂peak) and left ventricular diastolic dysfunction grade but did not affect endothelial function (FMD). No improvements were observed with MI-ACT, suggesting HIIT may be more effective for early exercise adaptations in HFpEF.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF), aged 70 ± 8.3 years.
effective_dosage: HIIT: 4 × 4 min at 85-90% peak heart rate, with 3 min active recovery, 3 days/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) in preventing or reversing sarcopenia by examining its effects on muscle strength and functional quality.
results_summary: The study suggests that HIIT, when combined with resistance training, promotes beneficial changes in skeletal muscle that may help counteract sarcopenia, though specific efficacy data are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals at risk of sarcopenia due to low physical activity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining high-intensity interval training with inspiratory-loaded core conditioning ("functional" IMT) enhances endurance running performance and economy compared to interval training alone.
results_summary: The study found that the intervention group (ICT) showed larger improvements in core muscle function, running economy, and 1-hour running performance compared to the control group (CON), suggesting that adding inspiratory-loaded core conditioning to interval training augments endurance performance benefits.
population_specificity: Sixteen recreational runners.
effective_dosage: Interval training: 3-4 sessions per week; functional IMT: 10 repetitions per set, 2 sets per day at 50% post-IMT inspiratory load.
study_duration: 6-week intervention phase (preceded by a 4-week foundation IMT phase).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the caloric expenditure of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) using a hydraulic resistance system (HRS) against resistance, aerobic, and combined exercise modalities of the same duration.
results_summary: HIIT with HRS resulted in significantly greater caloric expenditure, higher average heart rate, and higher perceived exertion compared to steady-state exercises like weight training, treadmill, and cycling. The study suggests HIIT with HRS is more effective for burning calories in a limited time.
population_specificity: Nine recreationally active men (age: 25 ± 7 years; height: 181.6 ± 7.6 cm; weight: 86.6 ± 7.5 kg).
effective_dosage: HIIT session included repeating intervals of 20 seconds at maximum effort followed by 40 seconds of rest for 30 minutes.
study_duration: Single 30-minute sessions for each exercise modality.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of 12 weeks of elliptical HIIT on metabolic risk factors and body composition in pre- and type 2 diabetes patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in fasting blood glucose, waist and hip circumference, appendicular fat mass, leg lean body mass, systolic blood pressure, resting heart rate, and VO2max. There were also trends toward reduced leg fat mass and diastolic blood pressure, as well as increased total energy expenditure.
